prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. Factor the expression $3x(x+1) + 7(x+1)$.
solution: We can factor the expression $x+1$ out of each term: \[3x(x+1) + 7(x+1) = \boxed{(3x+7)(x+1)}.\]
gpt_response:
First, let's look at the expression with the parentheses. We see that both terms have an $(x+1)$. In elementary school, we can think of it as the same as having two groups of things, one group with $3x$ things and another group with $7$ things. So if we take out the common factor of $(x+1)$, we get $$(3x + 7)(x + 1).$$

So the factored form of $3x(x+1) + 7(x+1)$ is $(3x + 7)(x+1)$.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to (3x+7)(x+1)?: First, let's look at the expression with the parentheses. We see that both terms have an $(x+1)$. In elementary school, we can think of it as the same as having two groups of things, one group with $3x$ things and another group with $7$ things. So if we take out the common factor of $(x+1)$, we get $$(3x + 7)(x + 1).$$

So the factored form of $3x(x+1) + 7(x+1)$ is $(3x + 7)(x+1)$.
